results.title: Peggy Sue got married
results.creator_credit: Tri-Star Pictures, Rastar Films, Zoetrope Studios, Paul R. Gurian and Francis Ford Coppola
results.brief_description: Disillusioned with her life and the disintegration of her marriage to her childhood sweetheart (Nicolas Cage), former prom queen Peggy Sue (Kathleen Turner) reluctantly attends her 25 year high school reunion. Confronted by her past, she begins to regret her life choices and missed opportunities. Emotionally overwhelmed, she collapses during the reunion and awakens as herself 25 years earlier. Armed with experience and a second chance, she sets out, determined not repeat the same mistakes. A comedy fantasy film also starring Joan Allen, Helen Hunt, Jim Carrey, Maureen O’Sullivan, Leon Ames, John Carradine. Script, Jerry Leichtling and Arlene Sarner. Music, John Barry. Editing, Barry Malkin. Cinematography, Jordan Cronenweth.

results.title: Pegged in
results.brief_description: The secret life of a peg! A comic animation of common wooden pegs who, once left alone in a laundry basket, come to life and sprout legs. This quirky short has the pegs getting caught up in a string, one burns itself of an iron, and they all conspire to release two of their fellow pegs from a shirt pocket, in the process cause chaos.

results.title: Pegged in
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School, David Atkinson, John Bird and Michael Eaglesome
results.brief_description: A handful of pegs get up to no good when the house lady leaves them alone with a basket full of freshly dried clothes. This student live animation is an excerise in punchline storytelling with a carefree humour and jazzy soundtrack.

results.title: Peer pressure: nobody tells me what to do
results.brief_description: Gary, an adolescent boy, wishes he was more like the school tough guys. However, a series of events involving shoplifting and breaking and entering help him to realize that he was in the right track to begin with

results.title: Peer pressure: learning to be yourself
results.creator_credit: Barr Films, Greg Logan and Renee Ross
results.brief_description: A fifteen-year-old girl learn to understand how she allows peer pressure to affect her life. Insecure and hoping for acceptance, she acts accordingly to gain approval. Her older brother helps her recognize that she should be paying more attention to her own feelings when makng decissions. Defines and discusses the more subtle types of peer pressure.

results.title: Peer pressure, drugs and you
results.creator_credit: Bossert and Company, Sunburst Communications, Carolyn Vanderslice and Robin Bossert
results.brief_description: Using case studies and examples, this program demonstrates assertiveness strategies for resisting peer pressure to use drugs. The program is divided into three parts, with each part examining a different aspect of peer pressure. This program will facilitate role-playing and provide techniques and strategies for resisting peer pressure in a number of situations.

results.title: Peer pressure trigger tapes (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Three exciting short films about peer pressure, 1)”Sticks and Toby”. Two best friends, a thin boy and a fat boy go swimming. Toby , the fat boy, is teased by a group of boys who want Sticks to join them. What should Sticks do? “The Gang”; Ting Lee wants to join a gang at her school. In her new hairstyle and jacket they finally accept her, but then they pressure her to smoke! “Tough Rules” Max and his friends do lots of fun things together. One day they decide they should each steal something, Max doesn’t like stealing , but doesn’t want to lose his friends.

results.title: Peer conducted behaviour modification (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Phillip R. Blake and Steven D McAdam
results.brief_description: Drs. Clement and Paterson discuss the roles of peers in child therapy. The film shows a program at the Oregon Institute which, having found that the child’s peers can undermine the work of both psychologists and parents, uses other children to reinforce the behaviour therapy.

results.title: Peeping Tom
results.creator_credit: Michael Powell (Theatre) Ltd and Michael Powell
results.brief_description: A withdrawn psychopath films young women as he impales them with the camera’s tripod, forcing them to watch their own death throes in a mirror mounted on the camera. Now considered a masterpiece, Michael Powell’s film foreshadowed the slasher genre.

constellations_other.name: Capturing first-person POV
constellations_other.description: A comparison of how videogames and feature films have used first person POV shots and sequences and how (for the latter) camera technology has impacted on this.

results.description: In 1960 “Peeping Tom” took a ferocious drubbing from the English critical establishment. Powell saw it not as a horror film but ‘a film of compassion, of observation and of memory … a film about the cinema from 1900 to 1960 … the opposite to a realistic film … a reverie’. A withdrawn psychopath, traumatised by childhood memories, films young women as he impales them with the camera’s tripod, forcing them to watch their own death throes in a mirror mounted on the camera. This is rendered genuinely disturbing as we are drawn into identification with the protagonist through Carl Boehm’s subtly controlled performance. Littered with internal cross references, this is a reflexively subversive film about the fascination of cinema, a film which seeks to make voyeurs of us all. Cast also includes Moira Shearer, Anna Massey and Maxine Audley.
description_for_label: In 1960 “Peeping Tom” took a ferocious drubbing from the English critical establishment. Powell saw it not as a horror film but ‘a film of compassion, of observation and of memory … a film about the cinema from 1900 to 1960 … the opposite to a realistic film … a reverie’. A withdrawn psychopath, traumatised by childhood memories, films young women as he impales them with the camera’s tripod, forcing them to watch their own death throes in a mirror mounted on the camera. This is rendered genuinely disturbing as we are drawn into identification with the protagonist through Carl Boehm’s subtly controlled performance. Littered with internal cross references, this is a reflexively subversive film about the fascination of cinema, a film which seeks to make voyeurs of us all. Cast also includes Moira Shearer, Anna Massey and Maxine Audley.
